Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Functional Perspective on Adaptive Radiation: Explaining Differences in the Adaptive Radiations of Mainland and Island Anolis Lizards
Award.AbstractNarration:
Adaptive radiation, in which a clade diversifies from an ancestral form to produce descendants adapted to utilize a wide variety of ecological niches, has become a topic of great recent interest. The evolutionary radiation of Anolis lizards in the Caribbean has become a textbook case study of adaptive radiation, demonstrating that independent radiations can converge on very similar adaptive traits. This project expands this work to ask why in some cases evolutionary diversification yields very different results. On each island in the Greater Antilles, evolutionary radiation has occurred, producing species specialized to use different parts of the habitat (e.g., twigs, grass, canopy). Amazingly, evolution has occurred independently on each island, producing the same set of habitat specialists. Detailed analysis has indicated that strong relationships exist among species between anatomy and habitat use. Long-legged species occur on broad surfaces, for example, and more arboreal species have better developed toepads. Functional studies have explained these relationships by determining the relationship between morphology and functional performance capabilities, on one hand, and between performance abilities and habitat use and behavior, on the other. Anolis has also radiated widely in mainland Central and South America. Although less studied, these lizards have clearly evolved in different ways. Mainland anoles are as diverse among themselves as are island anoles, but the mainland species differ anatomically from the islands species. Most strikingly, the relationship between anatomy and habitat use differs fundamentally between mainland and island anoles.

The PIs will investigate whether differences in the anatomy~ecology relationship result because the relationship between functional capabilities and ecology differ or because the relationship between anatomy and functional capabilities differs (or both). In addition, the PIs will seek explanations for the variation in anatomy~performance relationships between island and mainland lizards, focusing on the physiological properties of muscles. Jointly the data collected to address these goals will enable the PIs to address the question of why mainland anoles have radiated in fundamentally different ways than island anoles. Undergraduate students, including women and individuals from underrepresented groups, a postdoctoral fellow and foreign collaborators will receive unique interdisciplinary training. The PIs will work with the Harvard Museum of Natural History to develop an exhibit on Anolis as a model system for understanding how evolution works.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Historically, ideas about island evolution have been contradictory. On the one hand, the reduced number of species on oceanic islands means that many resources utilized on continents may be available on islands. This “ecological opportunity” is thought to be a critical prerequisite for evolutionary diversification; it is no coincidence that essentially all textbook cases of adaptive radiation come from clades found on islands or in island-like settings (e.g. lakes). Yet, on the other hand, reduced species richness on islands has led to the presumption that interspecific interactions are less intense and that as a result, island species rarely reinvade continental settings because they are not adapted to cope with strong competitive and predatory interactions. A flood of examples now shows this premise to be incorrect: island-to-mainland radiation is not a one-way street. Nonetheless, a disparity in evolutionary outcomes is still evident: species colonizing islands from continents can give rise to spectacular adaptive radiations, yet the converse has scarcely been reported. In this project,we have shown that continental radiations can result from island ancestors. Moreover, we demonstrated that a textbook case of island radiation, Caribbean Anolis lizards, is matched by equally impressive radiation of their continental descendants. Moreover, we show that mainland radiation has occurred in the presence of a diverse primordial clade of anoles, requiring a more nuanced view of the role of ecological opportunity in evolutionary diversification.

 

Our studies on the linkage between morphological variation among species and functional capabilities significantly advanced understanding of the form-function relationship and how both interspecific and intersexual differences arise. Examining species of Anolis lizards, we show the main driver of sprint speed is the variation in femur length for both males and females. However, differences exist between the sexes. For example, snout vent length and overall muscle mass are also good predictors of sprint speed in males, whereas no relationships between muscle mass and sprint speed was observed in females. With regard to the role of variation in muscle properties among species in determining sprint performance, only a few significant relationships were found between muscle architecture (fiber length, cross-sectional area) and sprint speed in male anoles, suggesting that overall muscles size, rather than muscle architecture, appears to be under selection.

 

We demonstrated convergent evolution in head shape among different categories of habitat specialists, termed ecomorphs,and that these convergent features related to functional capabilities (e.g., the evolution of tall, wide heads correlates with the evolution of higher bite forces. In addition, the processes affecting head shape variation can differ betweensexes, leading to sexual head shape dimorphism. These processes might, however,still depend on the habitat. Consequently, there could also be convergent evolution in head shape dimorphism among ecomorphs. However, we found no evidence for convergent evolution in sexual head shape dimorphism. Moreover, the sexual head shape dimorphism correlates poorly with bite force, suggesting that intersexual head shape differences are related to other functions. Different processes are thus driving the evolution of head shape and head shape dimorphism.

A fortuitous outcome of our research was the opportunity to study the impact of a hurricane on a population we were in the midst of studying. Immediately after we finished a survey of Anolis scriptus—a common, small-bodied lizard found throughout the Turks and Caicos archipelago—our study populations were battered by Hurricanes Irma and Maria. Shortly thereafter, we revisited the populations to determine whether morphological traits related to clinging capacity had shifted in the intervening six weeks and found that populations of surviving lizards differed in body size, relative limb length and toepad size from those present before the storm. Our serendipitous study, which to our knowledge is the first to use an immediately before and after comparison to investigate selection caused by hurricanes, demonstrates that hurricanes can induce phenotypic change in a population and strongly implicates natural selection as the cause. In the decades ahead, as extreme climate events are predicted to become more intense and prevalent, our understanding of evolutionary dynamics needs to incorporate the effects of these potentially severe selective episodes.

Many undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, some from groups underrepresented in science, were trained in this project; many have moved on to the next stage in their scientific careers. Results from the research were widely disseminated in the media and online.
